exercise: Create a new file named 'mode_test.txt' in write mode ('w'). Write a sentence to it, then close the file. Now open the file again in read mode ('r') and print its contents.
Open an existing file in append mode ('a'). Add a new line of text to the file. Then open the file in read mode and verify that your text was added to the end of the existing content.
Try to open a file in write mode ('w') and then immediately in read mode ('r') without writing anything. Explain what happens to the file's previous contents and why.
Create a file in 'w+' mode. Write several lines to it, then use seek(0) to reset the cursor, and read and print all the content you just wrote. Explain why seek(0) is necessary.
Open an existing file in 'r+' mode. Read its contents, then write a new line at the end of the file. Reset the cursor to the beginning and read the entire file again to verify your changes.
Compare the behavior of 'w+' and 'r+' modes by creating two identical files, then opening one with each mode. Write the same content to both and read them back. Explain the differences you observe.

Open a file in 'r+' mode and use the seek() method to position the cursor at the 10th character. Write a new string at that position. Read the entire file and explain how the original content was affected.

Create a function that takes a filename, mode, and content parameters. The function should handle all possible file modes correctly, including appropriate error handling if the mode is invalid or if the file doesn't exist when using 'r' or 'r+' modes.

Create a program that allows a user to select a file operation mode (read, write, append, read/write, write/read) through a text menu. Based on their selection, perform the appropriate file operation on a file named 'user_test.txt'.

Write a script that demonstrates the difference between all five file modes ('r', 'w', 'a', 'r+', 'w+') by performing the same sequence of operations with each mode on separate files. For each mode, try to read, write, and append content, then document which operations succeed or fail with each mode and why.
